title: Walmart | NetApp | Visa | MoneyForward | Publicis Sapient | Practo | JPMC | APTIV
content:
My Complete Interview Journey (2024-2025)

Experience : 7+ Years
Education : B.E. (Information Technology), UIT RGPV Bhopal (Tier-3 College)
Location : Bengaluru
Current Role : Sr. Associate Projects @ Cognizant (Client: American Express)
Skills: Java, Golang, React, Spring Boot, Microservices, System Design, Kafka, PostgreSQL, Kubernetes

**Complete Timeline**
Phase 1: http://leetcode.com/discuss/post/5724980/help-needed-boeing-cognizantamex-capgemi-e2ae/

Phase 2: 2025 Job Search

Starting Point: Cognizant AMEX (₹28.7 LPA)
Interview Period: July 2025 - August 2025
Notice Period: 90 days

**Publicis Sapient - Senior Software Engineer**
Tech Stack: Java, Spring Boot

Round 1: Java & Architecture: Java basics and Java 8 features, Spring Boot annotations, Microservice architecture discussions, Saga Pattern (choreography vs orchestration), and a basic API design exercise.
Round 2: Agile & Process: Focused on Agile practices, delivery workflows, team ownership, and collaboration.

Result: OFFER - ₹30 LPA (with a verbal promise of ₹38 LPA closer to the end of my notice period, Gave the initial offer then ghosted me).

**APTIV (WindRiver Division) - Software Engineer**
Tech Stack: Golang

Round 1: Technical:
DSA: Search in sorted rotated array.
API Design: Library Management System (CRUD for books/categories).
Golang basics: syntax, slices, maps.

Round 2: Deep Dive:
Golang concurrency: goroutines, channels.
A deep dive into my American Express project architecture, explaining design choices and trade-offs.
Behavioral: Most complex problem solved (shared the Amex pipeline story), and work I'm most proud of.

Result: INITIAL OFFER made, but after discussing salary expectations → GHOSTED.

**Walmart Global Tech - Senior Software Engineer**
Tech Stack: Java, Spring Boot

Interview Date: All rounds on the same day (9:30 AM - 4:00 PM IST)

Round 1: DSA:
Longest Common Prefix.
Rotate Array by K without extra memory.

Round 2: System Design - Notification System:

My Solution: Kafka-based event pipeline for scalability, idempotency using a notification ID, consumer groups for each channel (Email, SMS, Push), retries with exponential backoff + Dead Letter Queue for failures, Load Balancer + API Gateway as an entry point, DB schema (notification_id, status, priority, scheduled_ts), and API design (/v1/userRequests, /v1/reports).

Round 3: Low Level Design:

Extended the notification system with design patterns: Strategy Pattern for multiple notification channels, Retry Pattern with Resilience4j, and Observer Pattern for event listeners.

Round 4: Hiring Manager:

Behavioral questions (conflict handling, deadline pressure), a deep dive into my Amex data pipeline architecture, and project trade-offs/design decisions.

Result: OFFER ACCEPTED - ₹52.43 LPA (Target Total Pay as per offer letter). Breakdown: Annual Base Pay (₹35L) + Target Bonus (₹7L) + Target Stock (₹8.75L) + Retirals (₹1.68L). Joining September.

**NetApp - Software Engineer 3**
Tech Stack: Golang, React

Round 1: Mixed Technical:
HTTP request flow in Kubernetes (explained 200/403/500 responses).
PostgreSQL LISTEN/NOTIFY (discussed pgx.WaitForNotification for migrations).
API Design: Library Management System with CRUD operations.
DSA: Word occurrence in a sentence

Round 2: Golang & React:

Golang concurrency patterns (goroutines, channels), PostgreSQL FOR UPDATE SKIP LOCKED for migration handling.
React: Write textbox autofocus code (struggled with this).
DSA: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters.

Round 3: Advanced Topics:

Golang design patterns; Inheritance in Go (Couldn't answer properly).
React: hooks, context vs redux, React 19 new features.
DSA: Spiral Matrix - Solved with interviewer hints.

Round 4: Hiring Manager:

Distributed team challenges, conflict resolution, role expectations, and project fit.

Result: OFFER - ~₹51.24 LPA (₹41.8L Base + ₹3.34L Bonus + ~$7.3K RSUs/year). Declined for Walmart.

**Money Forward - Senior Fullstack Engineer**
Tech Stack: Java, Spring Boot, React
Location: Chennai

Round 1: Basics: Java OOPs concepts, Spring Boot controllers/annotations, DSA (First non-repeating character in a string - Solved).

Round 2: System Design - Attendance Management System:

My Solution: Kafka for clock-in/out events (async), DB sharded by office ID, caching for manager dashboard, WebSockets for ≤5s staleness, and report generation to S3 with pre-signed URLs.

Feedback - Areas I missed: Cache invalidation strategy not properly defined, should have handled duplicate events with idempotent consumers, needed a dedicated worker service for report generation.

Round 3: Hiring Manager: Scenario-based questions on mentoring, team motivation, and how my technical trainer experience helps in development.

Result: ON HOLD (They mentioned they would get back to me if they couldn't find another candidate).

**Visa - Staff Software Engineer (Cybersecurity + AI)**

Round 1: DSA:

Cycle Detection in Linked List: Solved in <5 minutes with edge cases.
Combination Sum III: Attempted in Go, partial solution, couldn't complete due to debugging issues. This was the critical miss.

Round 2: System Design - Twitter-like Feed:

My Solution: Services (User, Post, Feed, Follower), DB (Postgres, Cassandra, Redis), Pipeline (Kafka + Flink for async fanout), CDN for media, and Auth (OAuth2.0, API Gateway, LB, SSL/TLS). Also explained caching hot posts and inverted indexes for search.

Result: REJECTED - Likely due to the incomplete DSA solution in Round 1.

**Visa - (Cybersecurity Team - Second Opportunity)**
Visa contacted me again for another position with the cybersecurity team.
Round 1: DSA
Minimum Window Substring (LeetCode Hard) - Solved.
Round 2: Security Deep Dive
Intensive questions on security concepts: encryption, TLS, mTLS, certificates, HSM, detailed breakdown of how HTTPS works, Istio, and questions on my experience.
Result: After this round, they wanted to give me a CodeSignal assessment. I declined as it was in my last week of job search and I had already decided to join Walmart.

**JP Morgan Chase - Senior Software Engineer**
Tech Stack: Java, React, SQL

Round 1: Mixed Technical:
DSA - 3rd largest element: Solved in O(n). Interviewer asked for a Java 8 Streams version, and I blanked on the syntax.
SOLID principles & Singleton pattern with double-checked locking explained.
SQL - 2nd highest salary: Major failure here. I didn't know RANK() or DENSE_RANK() and failed to get the correct result with other methods.
 What I tried (WRONG):
WITH ranked_salaries AS (
SELECT salary, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY salary DESC) as rn
FROM employees )
SELECT salary FROM ranked_salaries WHERE rn = 2;

Result: REJECTED - The SQL knowledge gap was the primary reason.

**Practo - Software Engineer**
Tech Stack: Java, Spring Boot

Round 1: DSA: Maximum Subarray Sum & one more easy LeetCode problem - Solved.
Round 2: Mixed: DSA (Maze Path BFS - Solved), LLD (Strategy Pattern), Java 8 Streams, and SQL queries.
Round 3: System Design - Notification Service:
Requirements: Multiple channels, scheduled notifications, priority delivery, retries, status tracking, scale to 10M/day.
My Solution: APIs, DB Schema (indexed + sharded), Flow (LB → Service → Kafka topics), Retry (@Retryable + DLQ), auto-scaling consumers, and idempotency.

Result: REJECTED - No feedback provided.

Detailed Preparation

Technical Preparation:
Java & Spring Boot: "Concept and Coding" YouTube playlists, Baeldung articles, and hands-on projects.

System Design:
LLD: "Concept and Coding" LLD playlist, and implemented Design Patterns myself.
HLD: Followed "Concept and Coding," "Jordan has no life," igotaoffer, and hellointerview.
Data Structures & Algorithms: Practiced all topics from the LeetCode main page.
Behavioral: Used the STAR pattern for all responses.

title: Offer comparison Tide vs {Some Fintech Startup} | Remote |
content:
Should I switch ?
- 

Looking for some help and advice from the community on whether I should make a switch.

 Here are the details:

YOE: 4.5

Current Company Compenstation
- 
- Product Based Startup Fintech (Permanent Remote, not a big startup brand, mostly unknown in India)
- 44.85 LPA Base (39LPA Fixed + Target bonus 15% (5.85 LPA))

- Additional: full 12% match i.e 2,34,000 LPA (19500 per month PF) **Employer** PF (over and above fixed)

- No ESOPS

- Benefits: Standard benefits, 12Lakh Health insurance, 40K OPD (include dental, gym, vision) & Life cover 3X of Fixed Salary
- Time Spent in the company: 1 year.


New Company Offer (Tide ,India))
-


- Role: Engineer, Backend 3 (Equivalent to SDE 3 as per recruiter)
- Again a Product Based Startup Fintech (Remote, but they have offices in India, so not sure of the future working mode)
- 46 LPA Target base (44.62 LPA Fixed + 1.38 LPA Variable (3% of Target Base))
- Additional: Rs 21,600 per year Employer PF i.e 1800 per month (over and above)
- ESOPS around 3.8lakhs Lakh per year, total 15 lakhs vested over 4 years (For me it's paper money)
- Benefits: Standard benefits: 5 lakh Health Insurance, 20K OPD, Life cover 2x of fixed, 9000 WFH setup.


Some More details about both companies
- 
- **Current Company**
  - Fixed hours (has it's own pros and cons, work hours are 12pm to 9pm IST)
  -  micromanagement by manager, not so fun environment atleast for me, just work and shutdown.
  - no career and financial growth (Low hikes 3-5% yearly [might or might not get in coming mid year cycle], no scope for promotion for atleast 2-3 years)
  - No oncalls for now, as product we are building in the team is pretty new and low scale.

- **New Company**
  - Flexible Hours, general work hours standard IST time (as per recruiter)
  -  Not sure how things will be regarding manager and work life (Community people can comment), as what I have heard culture is good , but not sure.
  -  Career and Financial Growth (Of What i researched the hikes are again single digit here in Tide 4%-8%, 5% being average, promo chances low atleast for next 1.5 years, they have 6 months probation too)).

title: Seeking Advice: Microsoft L60 Offer – Should I Accept? | 2.2 YOE
content:
Hi everyone,

I recently received an offer from **Microsoft (L60 role)** and would love to get your thoughts before making a decision. I applied via the career portal and it was the Hiring drive of August.

### **Offer Details**
- **Base**: ₹21L per annum  
- **Stock (RSU)**: $40k vesting over 4 years  
- **Performance Bonus**: ~10% on average  
- **Total Comp (1st year)**: ~₹31L  

### **Concerns**
1. The recruiter mentioned that this is the **maximum offer**, as my current compensation is considered “low,” despite having **2+ years of experience**.
2. The role involves **intense on-call duties**: 1 week of 24/7 on-call every 5–7 weeks.
3. Work-life balance and nature of the project don’t seem appealing.

### **Current Situation**

title: Google University Grad 2026 | Interview experience| India
content:
# Google Interview Experience | University Grad 2026

This document outlines my experience during a technical interview for the Google University Grad 2026 role, focusing on a problem involving a monotonic stack.

---

## The Problem: Trapping Rain Water with Fountains 

I was asked a question that was a variation of the classic "Trapping Rain Water" problem.

### Problem Statement

You are given a 1D array of integers, `surface`, representing a height map. You are also given an array of indices, `fountains`, which are source points for water. Water flows from these fountains to the left and right, filling any areas lower than the fountain's height until it hits a "wall" (a point higher than or equal to the fountain) or the edge of the array. The goal is to determine the final water level across the surface.

### Example

-   `surface = [1, 2, 3, 4]`
-   `fountains = [1, 3]` (Fountains at index 1 (height 2) and index 3 (height 4))

---

## My Approach & Performance

Here is a breakdown of my performance during the interview, including timing and thought process.

### Approach 1: Brute Force

-   **Explanation (10 mins):** I first described the brute-force solution. For each fountain, simulate the water flow outwards (one pointer to the left, one to the right). Keep track of the maximum water level at each position.
-   **Complexity:**
    -   Time: `O(N * K)` where N is the number of points and K is the number of fountains.
    -   Space: `O(N)` to store the water levels.
-   **Coding (5 mins):** I successfully coded this solution quickly.

### Approach 2: Optimal (Monotonic Stack)

-   **Explanation (10 mins for initial dry run):** I identified that the problem could be optimized by pre-calculating the "next greater element" to the left and right for each point. This is a classic use case for a **monotonic stack**. My initial attempt to dry-run this approach was shaky and took a significant amount of time.
-   **Reset & Re-explanation (2-3 mins):** I took a moment to reset, then successfully explained the logic more clearly.
-   **Coding (5 mins):** I started coding the optimal logic but ran out of time. I was only able to get about halfway through the implementation.
Like, I coded the logic but did not return the array.
-   **Complexity:**
    -   Time: `O(N)` because the monotonic stack approach processes each element a constant number of times.
    -   Space: `O(N)` for the stack.

---

## Takeaways & Advice for Round 2

So, do any of you have feedback for me for Round 2?
And what are key things I should improve?

Is it **hire**/**lean hire**/**strong hire**?

title: Microsoft L60 || Interview Experience
content: **Background** Education: BE from Tier 1 YOE: less than 1 Current: Product MNC --- **Round 1: Online Assessment** (75 minutes) Q1: Priority queue based question (easy-medium) Q2: Bit manipulation, efficient precomputation of factorial and inverse alongwith combinatorics to pass all testcases (medium-hard) Solved both questions fully. --- **Loop Interviews** : All rounds happened on the same day a week after giving OA. **Round 2: Problem Solving** (DSA) (60 minutes) Interviewer mentioned 2 questions are to be solved in this round. Expectation was to write production ready code and provide testcases as well. However, I could solve only 1 question before time ran out. Q: Given a string and a vector of string of random `[start,end]` positions, we need to place bold tags: ` at start` and ` at end`. https://leetcode.com/problems/add-bold-tag-in-string/description/ Handled overlapping intervals by merging them. Implemented end to end optimal code and came up with testcases other than those which interviewer provided. Discussed some edge cases and code worked for all scenarios. Discussed TC and SC. Interviewer provided no hints/suggestions and was silent throughout. [Self Verdict: Lean Hire] **Round 3: Problem Solving** (DSA) (60 minutes) Q1: https://leetcode.com/problems/single-element-in-a-sorted-array/description/ Discussed brute force and optimal approach in detail with interviewer with dry run. Once we both agreed to the solution coded up working solution. Wrote testcases and discussed minor improvements for edge cases. Discussed TC. Q2: https://leetcode.com/problems/largest-number/description/ Discussed lexicographical approach then interviewer asked to think of several testcases and dry run them. Figured out the problem with my initial approach and discussed optimal approach with merge sort and heap sort. Wrote the recursive call tree for a sample case. Discussed TC and recursive call SC. Coding was not asked for this question. Q3: Explain BFS and DFS and discuss when to use. Discussed the traversal algorithms and data structures for implementation. Discussed about infinite branch problem of DFS. Discussed custom traversal approach based on some heuristic combining BFS and DFS for faster convergence like IDDFS. Also went through real-world use cases of such algorithms like BFS for social network analysis. Overall had lots of insightful discussion and interviewer was super friendly and helpful. Discussed the impact and use cases of AI for a SWE at Microsoft. [Self Verdict: Strong Hire] **Round 4: AA | Hiring Manager** (Behavioural+System Design) (60 minutes) Interviewer started with asking some behavioural questions regarding why thinking of job change and why Microsoft. Discussed about some areas of interest and past work experience. Q: Low Level Design of Snake and Ladder Game Requirements: R1: Board has NxM positions, cannot go beyond boundaries. R2: K players each rolling dice in round robin format. R3: Implement snakes and ladders. Both cannot be at same position. R4: Player needs to roll a 6 to start. R5: Rolling a 6 gives second chance to roll dice. R6: Three consecutive 6 means chance cancelled. R7: If roll is invalid turn goes over to next player. R8: Game concludes when any player reaches last position. Implemented all the requirements. Wrote structured classes, functions and data structures for players, position, board, and gameplay. Discussed some optimizations of time and space and implemented them. Interviewer pointed out some edge cases and made required edits. Had some time leftover and interviewer was in Copilot team so got a chance to discuss the latest developments of AI and LLM happening inside Microsoft and what might be coming next. [Self Verdict: Strong Hire] --- **Final Verdict** 🎉 Got verbal offer and document submission mail within 3 working days. Written offer was released after another week. title: Amazon | SDE 2 | Bangalore | Accepted
content:
Hi LC Community,

Recently I interviewed with Amazon for the SDE 2 role.

**R1** - DSA + LP
**DSA** - Similar to LC 380. Follow up was LC 381.
**LP** - A time when you went beyond your current responsibilities.

**R2** - DSA + LP
**DSA** - Design Twitter (LC 355)
**LP** - When you executed/implemented with less information

**R3** - HM (LLD+HLD)
Design BMS with focus on payments and concurrency (no double booking of seats)
**LP** - A time when you worked on multiple projects. How did you handle escalations during such times ?

**R4** - Bar Raiser (DSA + LP)
A design based DSA question.
**LP** - Questions around handling poor customer experience, times when things went wrong, instances where you designed APIs.

2 days after my bar raiser round, I received the congratulatory email.
After over 4 weeks, I received the offer letter.

**Compensation** -

Base - 42 LPA
RSUs - 220 units
First Year Sign on - 17L
Second Year Sign on - 13L
Relocation - 1.5L
First Year CTC - 62.5 LPA

Current Compensation - 18.36 LPA
YOE - 4
No competing offers

Tip : Make sure you're supporting your project's impact using measurable figures.

Happy to answer if there are any queries.

**Edit**
I am worried about the WLB at Amazon. Any advice around this would be helpful!

title: Docquity Holdings (PBS) Interview Experience | SDE-1(Entry level)
content:
*ABOUT ME*

Batch : 2021 - 2025
Branch : Electronics and Computer Engineering
College: J.C. Bose University of Science and Technology,YMCA Faridabad(Tier-2)

*COMPENSATION PROVIDED*

* 6 - Months Internship - 30-35k/month
* Full - Time Salary : 13L/Year (9-10 Base)


📝 Round 1: MCQs on Core CS Fundamentals
Task: Solve 15-20 MCQs on core CS topics within 20 minutes.
Difficulty Level: Easy to Medium
Topics Covered : Operating Systems,Databases,Computer Networks,OOPS.
Outcome: ✅ Selected for Round 2
Participants reduced from 245-250 to 170-180.

💻 Round 2: Online Assessment (OA)
Task: Solve 2 Medium-level DSA questions in 45 minutes:
Minimum Path Sum (a variation of the LeetCode problem)
Detect and Print Cycle in a Linked List
Outcome: ✅ Selected for Round 3
Participants count reduced to 15-20.

🤝 Round 3: Technical Interview 1 (First Hurdle)
This 1 hour 30-minute interview was conducted by a Senior Software Developer.
Topics Covered:
Introduction and Projects: Walkthrough of my work and contributions.
OOPs Concepts: Focus on Inheritance and Ambiguity.
OS Fundamentals: Deadlock conditions and Resource Allocation Graph (RAG).
SQL Queries: Write a query to find the 2nd largest salary and explore Joins.
Design Question: Design a college campus using OOPs concepts.
DSA: Deep dive into the Merge Intervals problem (discussing multiple approaches).
Outcome: ✅ Cleared with positive feedback!
Participants reduced to 12.

⚙ Round 4: Technical Interview 2 (Second Hurdle)
Another 1 hour 30-minute grilling session, this time with the Head of the Technical Team.
Topics Covered:
Networking: Session Layer, Tokenization, OSI Model, and Topologies.
OS: Process stack and its role in recursion.
DBMS: Indexing, SQL queries, and subqueries.
DSA: Min Heap implementation (I stumbled a bit here 😅).
Coding: Solve a Linked List problem to create alternate node representations in O(1) space.
Outcome: ✅ Appreciated for my approach and moved to the next round with encouragement!
Participants reduced to 8.

💡 Round 5: Technical Interview 3 (Final Battle)
This was a 45-minute session with a Senior Member who had been with the company for 8-9 years. It was a mix of technical and personal discussions.
Topics Covered:
Projects: Insights into my projects and their purpose.
Resume Discussion: In-depth exploration of my skills and hobbies.
Logical Thinking: Solved a FizzBuzz problem.
Concepts: Brief talk on ASCII values.
Future Goals: My vision for the next 5 years.
Outcome: The round went well, but unfortunately, I didn’t make it to the HR round.

*The Organization selected 4 out of last 6-8 candidates*

title: Autodesk SDE (C++) Offer Changed – No Stocks, Reduced Base | 3.5 YOE | Need Advice
content:
Hello Leetcoders,

I’ve recently received an offer from **Autodesk** for an SDE (C++)role.
I have 3.5 years of experience(in service based company) and current pay is 11.5 LPA(all fixed), and the compensation offered is:

Base: ₹19.5 LPA
Variable: 8% of base salary

However, based on my research and industry standards, I feel this is a lowballed offer.

Initially during discussions with HR, and after a few rounds of negotiation, we had aligned and finalized the following offer structure:

Base: ₹22.5 LPA
Variable: 8% of base
Stocks: $25K worth of RSUs vested over 4 years

But after two weeks, I was informed that due to policy changes, they are no longer offering RSUs and have also reduced the base pay. I'm not sure how accurate this explanation is.

Unfortunately, I don’t have a competing offer at the moment to use as leverage — this is my first offer in this job search cycle. And hardly  getting any interview calls who can give more than this

That said, my interviews went exceptionally well
hiring manager explicitly expressed being impressed.

Given this context, I’d like to seek advice:
👉 What is the realistic or maximum compensation I can negotiate for at Autodesk for an SDE role with 3.5 YOE in C++ backend dev?
👉 And does the company has really stopped giving RSUs?.
